section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: By Your Power, You have set this false contrivance in motion. ||2||

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Some collect hundreds of thousands of dollars,

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Gauree Poorbee:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਸੁਰਗ ਬਾਸੁ ਨ ਬਾਛੀਐ ਡਰੀਐ ਨ ਨਰਕਿ ਨਿਵਾਸੁ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Don't wish for a home in heaven, and don't be afraid to live in hell.

transliteration.text: surag bās n bāshīai darīai n narak nivās .

melody.description: Gauri Purbi contains strong emotions of experience along with feelings of preparation, in order to go further and to achieve more. Although there are confident feelings in this Raag, there is a sense of uncertainty as there is a heart felt request for help to achieve the desired goal. The sentiments of this Raag are well considered assessments of the circumstances, without excess confidence or extreme helplessness.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਹੋਨਾ ਹੈ ਸੋ ਹੋਈ ਹੈ ਮਨਹਿ ਨ ਕੀਜੈ ਆਸ ॥੧॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Whatever will be will be, so don't get your hopes up in your mind. ||1||

transliteration.text: hōnā hai sō hōī hai manah n kījai ās .1.

melody.description: Gauri Purbi contains strong emotions of experience along with feelings of preparation, in order to go further and to achieve more. Although there are confident feelings in this Raag, there is a sense of uncertainty as there is a heart felt request for help to achieve the desired goal. The sentiments of this Raag are well considered assessments of the circumstances, without excess confidence or extreme helplessness.

translation.text: Sing the Glorious Praises of the Lord,

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: from whom the most excellent treasure is obtained. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: jā tē pāīai param nidhān .1. rahāu .

text: ਕਿਆ ਜਪੁ ਕਿਆ ਤਪੁ ਸੰਜਮੋ ਕਿਆ ਬਰਤੁ ਕਿਆ ਇਸਨਾਨੁ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: What good is chanting, penance or self-mortification? What good is fasting or cleansing baths,

transliteration.text: kiā jap kiā tap sanjamō kiā barat kiā isanān .

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: unless you know the way to worship the Lord God with loving devotion? ||2||

transliteration.text: jab lag jugat n jānīai bhāu bhagat bhagavān .2.

text: ਸੰਪੈ ਦੇਖਿ ਨ ਹਰਖੀਐ ਬਿਪਤਿ ਦੇਖਿ ਨ ਰੋਇ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Don't feel so delighted at the sight of wealth, and don't weep at the sight of suffering and adversity.

transliteration.text: sanpai dēkh n harakhīai bipat dēkh n rōi .

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: As is wealth, so is adversity; whatever the Lord proposes, comes to pass. ||3||

transliteration.text: jiu sanpai tiu bipat hai bidh nē rachiā sō hōi .3.

translation.text: Says Kabeer, now I know that the Lord dwells within the hearts of His Saints;

transliteration.text: kah kabīr ab jāniā santan ridai majhār .

translation.text: Gauree:

text: ਰੇ ਮਨ ਤੇਰੋ ਕੋਇ ਨਹੀ ਖਿੰਚਿ ਲੇਇ ਜਿਨਿ ਭਾਰੁ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: O my mind, even if you carry someone's burden, they don't belong to you.

transliteration.text: rē man tērō kōi nahī khinch lēi jin bhār .

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:

text: ਬਿਰਖ ਬਸੇਰੋ ਪੰਖਿ ਕੋ ਤੈਸੋ ਇਹੁ ਸੰਸਾਰੁ ॥੧॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: This world is like the perch of the bird on the tree. ||1||

transliteration.text: birakh basērō pankh kō taisō ih sansār .1.

translation.text: I drink in the sublime essence of the Lord.

text: ਜਿਹ ਰਸ ਬਿਸਰਿ ਗਏ ਰਸ ਅਉਰ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: With the taste of this essence, I have forgotten all other tastes. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: jih ras bisar gaē ras aur .1. rahāu .

text: ਅਉਰ ਮੁਏ ਕਿਆ ਰੋਈਐ ਜਉ ਆਪਾ ਥਿਰੁ ਨ ਰਹਾਇ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Why should we weep at the death of others, when we ourselves are not permanent?

transliteration.text: aur muē kiā rōīai jau āpā thir n rahāi .

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

text: ਜੋ ਉਪਜੈ ਸੋ ਬਿਨਸਿ ਹੈ ਦੁਖੁ ਕਰਿ ਰੋਵੈ ਬਲਾਇ ॥੨॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Whoever is born shall pass away; why should we cry out in grief? ||2||

transliteration.text: jō upajai sō binas hai dukh kar rōvai balāi .2.

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

text: ਜਹ ਕੀ ਉਪਜੀ ਤਹ ਰਚੀ ਪੀਵਤ ਮਰਦਨ ਲਾਗ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: We are re-absorbed into the One from whom we came; drink in the Lord's essence, and remain attached to Him.

transliteration.text: jah kī upajī tah rachī pīvat maradan lāg .

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

text: ਕਹਿ ਕਬੀਰ ਚਿਤਿ ਚੇਤਿਆ ਰਾਮ ਸਿਮਰਿ ਬੈਰਾਗ ॥੩॥੨॥੧੩॥੬੪॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Says Kabeer, my consciousness is filled with thoughts of remembrance of the Lord; I have become detached from the world. ||3||2||13||64||

transliteration.text: kah kabīr chit chētiā rām simar bairāg .3.2.13.64.

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. translation.text: Raag Gauree:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਪੰਥੁ ਨਿਹਾਰੈ ਕਾਮਨੀ ਲੋਚਨ ਭਰੀ ਲੇ ਉਸਾਸਾ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The bride gazes at the path, and sighs with tearful eyes.

transliteration.text: panth nihārai kāmanī lōchan bharī lē usāsā .

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.
